name: KING'S INDIAN DEFENSE
uci_moves: d2d4 g8f6 c2c4 g7g6 b1c3 f8g7 e2e4 d7d6
idea: The most combative defense against 1.d4! Black lets White build a massive e4-d4 center, then launches a furious kingside attack with ...e5, ...f5, ...Nf6-d7-f6, ...g5, ...Rf7-g7 and ...h5. It's a real battle: White attacks on the queenside (c5, b4) while Black attacks the White King. Kasparov and Fischer won immortal games with this opening. Very theoretical but spectacular!
errors_white: Ignoring Black's kingside attack: the ...f5, ...g5, ...h5 attack can be devastating
Playing too slowly on the queenside: the race is on, you must push c5, b4, a4 quickly
Exchanging the Bg7 without reason: this Bishop is Black's strength but also a King defender
errors_black: Never playing ...f5: without this push the attack doesn't exist, Black gets crushed
Playing ...e5 then ...exd4: opens the center for White, you must keep the tension
Forgetting defense: attacking is good, but the Black King must also be protected!
development: d6 first (solid), then ...e5 to block the center and prepare ...f5
The monster of the King's Indian! Targets d4, a1 and defends the King
Attacks e4, then often ...Nfd7 to prepare ...f5 without blocking the f-pawn
Kingside castle, then the King stays on g8 during the f5-g5-h5 attack
After ...f5, the Rook goes to f7, then g7 or h7 for the attack!

traps.name: Center Trap
traps.desc: Classical position. If Black plays ...e5 too early without preparation, 6.dxe5 dxe5 7.Qxd8 Rxd8 8.Nxe5! wins a pawn. AVOID (Black): Play ...e5 only after 0-0, or play ...Nbd7 first.

traps.name: Four Pawns Attack
traps.desc: 5.f4!? Aggressive attack. The 4 pawns e4-d4-c4-f4 are imposing but Black plays ...c5! to counter-attack. AVOID (Black): Don't be passive! ...c5 immediately to open the game.

traps.name: Bayonet Attack Trap
traps.desc: Bayonet Attack: White plays b4 to attack. Black must respond quickly with ...f5 or ...a5. AVOID (Black): Don't play passively! ...f5 or ...a5 to create counterplay.

variants.name: Classical Variation
variants.uci: d2d4 g8f6 c2c4 g7g6 b1c3 f8g7 e2e4 d7d6 g1f3 e8g8 f1e2 e7e5 e1g1 b8c6 d4d5 c6e7
variants.white_plan: Closed center. Queenside attack with c5, b4, a4, Rb1. The Knight goes to d3 to support c5 or b4.
variants.black_plan: Kingside attack! ...Nd7, ...f5, then ...f4, ...g5, ...Nf6, ...Rf7-g7, ...h5-h4 to open the lines.

variants.black_plan: ...c6 prepares ...cxd5. Plans: ...a6, ...b5 or ...f5 after preparation. ...Nh5 to exchange the Be3.

variants.white_plan: Imposing but fragile center. cxd5 or exd5 depending on desired structure. 0-0 and attack with e5.
variants.black_plan: Counter-attack! ...exd5 opens lines for the Bg7. ...Bg4, ...Re8, ...Qa5 with active play.
